<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18724>

Martin Maechler (<mailto:maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch|maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
     Ever confirmed|0                           |1
                 CC|                            |maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |ASSIGNED

--- Comment #3 from Martin Maechler (<mailto:maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch|maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch>) ---
(In reply to David from comment #2)
> Actually if it is possible I would like to try making a patch myself!

Really neither is necessary.  Sometimes a bug report is really the most
efficient way for R-core ... and it is in this case.

I'll commit the "obvious" fix (use `vapply()`)  after some testing.

text:
*[Bug 18133] R on Windows does not remove one of its own test files in TMPDIR*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18133>

--- Comment #11 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
I've updated the code now so that the behavior of calling closeNode() is closer
to what it has been before, at the expense of the code being slightly less
readable.

If that still causes problems for some of your code, it would be useful if you
could provide a concrete example. The change was in undocumented behavior
rather than in the public API, and it was tested on CRAN/Bioconductor package
checks: it is hard to predict the impact on unknown code.

elements.text: [Bug 18133] R on Windows does not remove one of its own test files in TMPDIR

) ---
I've updated the code now so that the behavior of calling closeNode() is closer
to what it has been before, at the expense of the code being slightly less
readable.

If that still causes problems for some of your code, it would be useful if you
could provide a concrete example. The change was in undocumented behavior
rather than in the public API, and it was tested on CRAN/Bioconductor package
checks: it is hard to predict the impact on unknown code.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------
             Status|ASSIGNED                    |CLOSED
         Resolution|---                         |FIXED

--- Comment #4 from Sebastian Meyer (<mailto:seb.meyer@fau.de|seb.meyer@fau.de>) ---
So I have committed this trivial fix in c86547 as suggested by the OP. The
practical relevance of `sealClass()` is very low as noted above, but I saw no
reason for not fixing this bug.

text:
*[Bug 17866] nlme gls() results for unbalanced data with corStruct correlation class change if Initialize() is called first*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=17866>

Sebastian Meyer (<mailto:seb.meyer@fau.de|seb.meyer@fau.de>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
     Ever confirmed|0                           |1
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CONFIRMED
                 CC|                            |seb.meyer@fau.de

--- Comment #1 from Sebastian Meyer (<mailto:seb.meyer@fau.de|seb.meyer@fau.de>) ---
Thanks for the detailed report. I confirm this bug.

Exercising Initialize() for "corStruct" objects outside of gls() or lme() is
well in scope of nlme: there are plenty of examples in the documentation and
the book. However, passing an already initialized correlation structure to the
model calls is not, it seems.  AFAICS, this approach is not used anywhere in
nlme's own documentation or tests at least, so is non-standard.

I suspect the problem is that lme() and also gls() (when there are grouping
variables) internally reorder the data by these, but an already initialized
"corStruct" won't get re-initialized so the stored `Dim()`ensions associated
with the grouping factor are misaligned. So the simplest solution might be to
disallow passing pre-initialized correlation structures to gls() etc. This
needs a closer look.

elements.text: [Bug 17866] nlme gls() results for unbalanced data with corStruct correlation class change if Initialize() is called first

) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added

                 CC|                            |seb.meyer@fau.de
